text: Thank you to Squarespace for sponsoring this video.

[BoJack Horseman]
Are you kidding me? He looks nothing like me!
In many sitcoms of the past, achieving and maintaining happiness is no big deal.

Every problem is easily solved,
the moral lessons are simple,

everyone hugs it out, and just like that,
the narrative is wrapped up in a bow.
The result is a pleasant, albeit fake, sense of closure.
Netflix's satirical cartoon, "Bojack Horseman",
explores the pitfalls of these types of narratives in American media.
The show contrasts BoJack's sitcom life in "Horsing Around"...
Sarah Lynn: Maybe it's just because I never had a Christmas before.
But this is the best Christmas I've ever had.
BoJack: Me too.
[they hug it out & audience goes "aww"]

...with his real life, full of self-loathing,
broken friendships and borderline nihilism.
One ends, and everything gets wrapped up nice and simple,
the other goes on with complexity and uncertainty.
This contrast is obvious - but it's important, because it's central
to the philosophy of the show and its creator Raphael Bob-Waksberg.
"I don't believe in endings

I think you can fall in love, and get married,
and you can have a wonderful wedding.
But then you still have to wake up the next morning, and you're still you.

You can have the worst day of your life, but then,
the next day won't be the worst day of your life.

And I think it works in a positive and a negative,
that all these things that happen, are moments in time.
And that because of the narrative we've experienced, we've all kind of internalized this idea,
that we're working towards some great ending.
And that if we put all our ducks in a row, we'll be rewarded, and everything will finally make sense.

But the answer is, that everything doesn't
make sense... at least, as far as I've found."

We see the characters reference this
philosophy throughout the series.

BoJack: Closure is a made-up thing by
Steven Spielberg, to sell movie tickets!
Or in Diane's words:

Look, the wedding was great, but that's not real life.
I mean, I guess I got a happy ending.
But every happy ending has the day after the happy ending, right? And the day after that.
The idea, that life doesn't have happy endings, but is rather a series

of positive and negative moments in time,
is the foundation of the entire show.
Unlike many of its predecessors, BoJack is serialized,

meaning, the episodes don't need to be
wrapped up with some nice ending.
The story is on a long timeline, rather than self-contained loops, so tension is never fully released.
The characters, and by extension the viewer, have an ever-present anxiety about where their life will go next.
In doing so, the show not only subverts a lot of traditional television,
but also becomes more honest to real life.
The characters change, but only if they're willing and they put the work in.
It turns out to be a long, arduous process for all of them.
They have to take things day-by-day.
There are no easy answers and no easy fixes to the problems in their lives.

And, according to Bob-Waksberg, that's the
underlying ethos of the show: existing is hard.

For the show's titular character BoJack, who lives
with clinical depression, that's especially true.

It's not something that has closure,
it's something you live with, day to day.

BoJack's issue is that he wants life
to be as simple, as it is in a sitcom.

He wants easy closure. He's always
seeking validation and forgiveness,

but unlike his sitcom, where they're guaranteed,
in real life he never earns them.

Interestingly enough, not getting this
closure only exacerbates his problems.

And he continues his own loops of addiction,
self-destruction, and driving away his friends.
In other words, believing that life can be this way only makes his life harder.
One cycle contributes to the other.

The show juxtaposes this hope for easy closure
against BoJack's real life throughout the show.

In sitcom life, getting closure for doing
something wrong is an easy task.
Sarah Lynn: I'm sorry I broke your expensive bachelor vase. [audience aww's]
BoJack: That's alright, I've learned that when you're in a loving family,
there's nothing wrong with a little...
horsing around. [audience laughs]

But forgiveness isn't always that easy in real life.
The truth is, negative actions compound over time.

BoJack: Todd, I'm sorry, alright? I screwed up.
I know I screwed up. I don't know why...

Todd Chavez: Oh great, of course. Here it comes!
You can't keep doing this!
You can't keep doing shitty things, and then feel bad about yourself, like that makes it okay!

Todd: You need to be better!
BoJack: I know. And I'm sorry, okay?

I was drunk, and there was all this
pressure with the Oscar campaign...
But now - now that it's over, I...
Todd: No! No, BoJack, just stop. You are all the things that are wrong with you.

It's not the alcohol, or the drugs,
or any of the shitty things

that happened to you in your career,
or when you were a kid. It's you!
To think anyone can hit the reset button for their actions, by showing remorse
over and over again, is not a solution in real life. They need to earn forgiveness.
This contrast is also made between the closure that movies give, and BoJack's real life.
In most movies, the story ends on a high note,
inspiring everyone to believe, that deep down, they are a good person.
Movie BoJack: Being Secretariat isn't just about running fast,
Secretariat's a state of mind.

It's about doing the right thing,
and standing up for yourself.
Why, I look around, and I see a whole room full of Secretariats!
You are Secretariat, and you are Secretariat, and you are Secretariat.
The show however, says just because a story tells you you're a good person, it's no guarantee you are one.

Herb Kazzaz: You know what your problem is?
You wanna think of yourself as the good guy!

Well, I know you better than anyone,
and I can tell you that you're not.

In fact, you'd probably sleep a lot better at night,
if you just admitted to yourself that you're a selfish,

goddamn coward, who takes whatever he wants,
and doesn't give a shit about who he hurts.
Again, here we see belief conflict with action.
You can't just believe you're a good person, you have to earn it.
And that's where this idea of "closure vs. moments in time" even separates the show from a lot of other satire.

A lot of good satire deconstructs the world for us,
helping us become aware of our flaws.

But a lot of satirical characters
don't change because of closure.
They need to re-establish the status quo by the next episode,

so they can deconstruct next week's issue
through their unchanging personality.

And, much like these sitcom characters,
BoJack never really learns or changes either.
Bob-Waksberg takes this a step further,
by saying self-awareness and deconstruction alone aren't good enough.
I notice this all the time, when I watched shows like South Park or Seinfeld.

They deconstruct an issue for me, and I say "Oh,
that's a problem in the world, or a problem in my life.

I should do something about it",
only to forget about it the next day.
While I admit that laughing and catharsis are ends in themselves,
it's refreshing to see a show take the opinion,

that what you know deep down doesn't matter,
if you don't take action on it.

Diane Nguyen: I don't think I believe in deep down.
I kind of think all you are, is just the things that you do.
In other words, if your actions never show that you're a good person, then are you really a good person?
It's one of the key messages the show is always putting forward.
Being a good person requires a constant dialogue between self-awareness, and taking action on being better.

It means keeping your needs in mind,
but never forgetting the needs of others.
At the same time, there are still no guarantees that doing this is easy,
or that your actions will always be rewarded. Existing is hard.
What's also interesting about Bob-Waksberg's philosophy of "positive and negative moments in time",
is its redefinition of how happiness works.
Corporatized, entertaining narratives tend to push this idea,
that there's something out there, that will finally make us happy, permanently.

Whether it be love or marriage,
maybe it's power, money or fame.

By saying, that life is all positive
and negative moments in time,

that it's ongoing with no endings,
happiness is redefined as ephemeral.
The show references this ephemeral nature of happiness constantly.
Ana Spanakopita: This has been your dream for the last 30 years. You made it happen.

An Oscar won't make you happy forever.
It won't solve all your problems.

You win that Oscar - the next day,
you go back to being you.
But that night is a really good night.

BoJack, unfortunately, believes in this idea,
that there's some great ending for him out there.
He's always looking for that one last thing, that will make everything better, and he'll be permanently happy.
In Season 1, he expects he'll be happy once he finishes his book.

Diane Nguyen: What would make you happy?
BoJack: Well, finishing my memoir, I guess.
In Season 2, he expects getting his dream role of "Secretariat" will finally make him happy.
In Season 3, he expects getting an Oscar will make him happy.
In every case this expectation becomes toxic.
It's precisely his hope, that something will make him happy forever, that exacerbates his depression.
Again, one cycle contributes to the other.

Which brings us to this moment, when
the show solidifies its stance on happiness.
Cuddlywhiskers explains, that he expected an Oscar to make him happy, and it didn't.

He then explains, that he tried to find purpose
in helping addicts at a halfway house,

but that too left him empty.
And then he says this:

Cuddlywhiskers:
Sometimes you need to take responsibility for your own happiness.

Diane Nguyen:
You don't think that's a little selfish?

Cuddlywhiskers:
I don't know what to tell you.

II'm happy for the first time in my life,
and I'm not gonna feel bad about it.
It takes a long time to realize how truly miserable you are,
and even longer to see, that it doesn't have to be that way.

Only after you give up everything,
can you begin to find a way to be happy.

He's not saying give up your goals,
or helping people, or not striving at all.

It's about giving up searching
for happiness in those things.

It's an idea central to stoic philosophy.
In the words of Greek philosopher Epictetus:
Indeed, expecting happiness from things whether it be from the past,
present or future, puts whatever that thing is in control of you.
But happiness doesn't come from external events themselves - it comes from your judgments about them.

It's one way to, as Cuddlywhiskers said,
"Take responsibility for your own happiness".
Changing your thinking is more likely to make you happy,
than changing the world, to make it conform to your wishes.

The Closer: The universe is a wild beast.
You can't tame it. All you can do, is try to live inside it.

But wait a second! If you just accept reality,
and don't have expectations,
then doesn't that neglect the whole idea of caring and striving?
Isn't it selfish, just as Diane said?
Well, you can still care, as long as you're willing to ride the wave of positive and negative moments in time.

"If you expect your life to be up and down,"
wrote the Buddhist monk Lama Yeshe,
"your mind will be much more peaceful".

You can still care, as long as you know
things will go south sometimes.

The important thing to remember, is that
happiness always arises as a by-product.

As Shakespeare knew long ago,
"The joy is in the doing".

All of this is going to be really hard for BoJack,
with the way his mind works in his dramatic history.
That said, he's showing some improvement.
In Season 4, he finally listens to Cuddlywhiskers' advice.
He gives up L.A. and everything it has to offer.

The self-reflection that he does while he's gone,
helps him realize that he's hurt a lot of people.
Only then does he begin to find a way to mend things with Todd.
He gives up thinking about his legacy for being a talented actor,
and blindly accepts an offer to act in one of Princess Carolyn's shows.
It helps him reconnect with her.
He gives up a little bit of his animosity towards his mother,
leaving her on a positive note, and breaking the cycle of abuse between them.
And finally, he gives up Hollyhock by dropping off the information
she so desperately wanted, knowing he might never see her again.
Interestingly enough, it's the reason he reconnects with her.
He finally capitalizes on the advice he received in Season 1.

Diane Nguyen:
You can't force love, you blockhead.
All you can do is be good to the people in your life, and keep your heart open.

It's still going to be hard for him. Who knows,
where Bob-Waksberg wants to take the story.

But his cycles appear to be breaking for now.
It's clear he started to confront the fact,

that he'll never not be depressed,
and that it's okay to be that way.

As long as he knows, that he can
work each day to get a little better,

take responsibility for his actions,
and learn to live with himself as he is.
BoJack's belief in these narratives was toxic for a long time.

His attempt to use them as an easy escape
from his real life, only made his life worse.

And while it's important to escape every once in a while,
it's dangerous to believe, that this closure applies to life.
Like BoJack, we escape into narrative constantly.

We're a mass-media saturated audience,
that all too often replaces pop culture

with the harder tasks of intimacy, self-reflection,
and building meaningful friendships.

The truth, is you can fake your reality all you want,
but that's not going to make your life better.
The show encourages us to break these cycles.
To redefine our narrative as one, that happens day to day - not one, that has some great ending.
And that no matter what cards we're dealt in life,

we have an individual responsibility for
our actions and our happiness each day.

Everyone has a story to tell.
It just may not be the one you see in the media.

And so, when BoJack asked Diane
"Do you think it's too late for me?",

hoping desperately for confirmation,
that he's deep down a good person,
the truth is - no, having problems and being messed up don't mean the story is over.
It just means, that's where you are for this moment in time.
The solution for BoJack is no different for anyone else.

Jogging Baboon: It gets easier.
BoJack Horseman: Huh?

Baboon: Every day, it gets a little easier.
BoJack: Yeah?

Baboon: But you gotta do it every day.
That's the hard part. But it does get easier.
[BoJack panting]
BoJack: ...okay.
Hey everyone, thank you so much for watching.
I just wanna talk about designing my new website with Squarespace.
They have this really intuitive easy-to-use platform,

that made the process painless for someone like me,
who hasn't written the line of code, ever.

They have award-winning designer templates,
they do domains, they have 24/7 customer service...
It really is an all-in-one platform, where you can build a good-looking website. I'm really happy with it.
You can start your free trial today. Go to squarespace.com/WillSchoder to get 10% off your first purchase.
I wanna thank my Patrons over on Patreon for their support, uh...
You all allow me to spend more time researching, writing and producing these episodes. I really appreciate it.

I'm on a big push to make this my full-time job,
and Patreon is a big part of making that happen.

I also wanted to say, that it's just past my
one-year anniversary of making videos,

and seeing the community around
this channel grow has been amazing.
I'm excited to talk with everyone down in the comments.
Other than that, I'll see you guys next time.
I'm tired of running in circles [x1]
I'm tired of running in circles [x2]
I'm tired of running in circles [x3]
I'm tired of running in circles [x4]
I'm tired of running in circles [x5]
